conclusion: Understanding initial conditions with blocks A and B connected by a spring.
System is at rest, blocks in equilibrium, forces on A and B described.
Definitions of variables m, k, F, g.
Finding initial equilibrium position for block A: mg = kx, so x = mg/k.
Net force on A when F is applied: F - mg - kx.
Considering forces on block B: N + kx = mg, N = mg - kx.
Re-evaluating N = mg - kx = 0, spring force supports block B.
Reconsidering forces on A and B with free-body diagrams.
Re-evaluating spring force directions: A up, B down.
Reaffirming initial compression of spring: x = mg/k.
Re-evaluating N = mg - kx = 0, spring force supports block B.
Net force on A when F is applied: F - mg + kx, x = mg/k.
Net force on A simplifies to F, acceleration a = F/m.
Considering equilibrium position where B just leaves the ground.
When B leaves the ground: mg - kx = 0, x = mg/k.
Total displacement from initial position: initially compressed by mg/k, extended by mg/k.
